author: eaoe
content: How many bytes is each gas ?

author: trent_vanepps
content:
gas doesn't reference bytes. it's an internal measure the EVM uses to assign costs to specific computation / operations. for example, a "simple send" of ETH from one address to another costs 21,000 gas

this gets multiplied by each transactions associated baseFee + priorityFee per gas (aka tip) resulting in the total tx cost in ETH / $

baseFee and priorityFee fluctuate according to congestion

(pls anyone correct me if I'm wrong here)

author: eaoe
content:
It is mainly to cover the three resources used in a transaction (Bandwidth, computational power, and storage) so a transfer might consume 2,000,000 gas due to computational power or bandwidth but store too little, I think a regular ETH transfer consumes the most storage with respect to its gas, smart contracts fees are mostly spent on computational power, so i think the best way to calculate an approximate of the maximum storage is by calculating how many many bytes each regular ETH transfer costs and multiply that by how many are possible in one block (block size limit / 21000)

(Someone please correct me if i'm thinking wrong)

author: sky.cactus
content: If your goal is to burn storage, there are much more efficient ways than ETH transfers.

author: eaoe
content: i was lost in calculation i forgot KB comes before MB so my end result was 1.8 GB

author: potuz
content: <@683653554631868440> curious if you or anyone found some successful transaction from the responsible today. Was there actually an intent to double spend or was it only to disrupt the network? This incident shows it's pretty hard to fix a bug in open source projects and announce the release in advance and make it public. I wonder if no fuzz were made about this release what would have happened. In principle it could be much worse if people didn't care to upgrade

author: gcolvin
content: I think it was malicious.  And there did look to be a pump-and-dump during the event, but I didn't manage to track it down.  I think <@!211091239112671234> is writing a post-mortem.  And yeah, coordinating upgrades is especially hard when out-of-sync clients can break consensus.

author: potuz
content: That it was malicious is clear as the code of that contract is only to trigger the bug. But I can imagine that they didn't get anything from it if all exchanges were upgraded

author: trianglesphere
content: I lean towards it being a griefer. It could be different actors, but it seems that some form of this transaction has been ran on most EVM chains

author: holiman
content: https://twitter.com/mhswende/status/1431350139386540033

author: holiman
content: We've done silent patches (official policy: https://geth.ethereum.org/docs/vulnerabilities/vulnerabilities ) -- but doing a silent patch means 3-4-6 weeks of anticipation: "are enough upgraded yet? anyone found it yet?". It can go really really bad. And no matter what path we choose, you can be sure we'll be blamed

author: treyzania
content: I'm not 1000% sure I found the right bug but looking at the portion of the diff between .8 and .7 related to the evm interpreter that changed I wouldn't say it's that hard to find

author: treyzania
content: I skimmed it last week and figured it'd have *something* to do with what I saw but I didn't bother looking deeper until this morning

author: treyzania
content: trying hard to get people to upgrade was a good choice

author: potuz
content: Yeah I feel for you, I can see it's a lose-lose situation

author: treyzania
content: but seeing "oh look they changed something very specific about the VM interpreter I wonder what that's about" in the diff even without knowing there's a vuln could be a huge hint to look for a vuln

author: treyzania
content: maybe if the patch was hidden in a larger refactor that would have bought more time

author: holiman
content: Yeah, but going from "something related to memory" to the specific exploit was, in this case, not trivial. I promise you. I even triaged it on a very _very_ good evm hacker. We'll publish a writeup later. In this case, it took from tuesday morning to friday afternoon, which I guess was enough (but I had thought it would be more)

author: holiman
content: And it was. But the patch had to be applied to Erigon and lots of other projects, which in some cases couldn't take the whole PR, but just the actual patch, so that made it easier for an astute observer to narrow it down

author: treyzania
content: that's a good point

author: trianglesphere
content: One thing that is helpful here is that there's not typically a large overlap between people who understand the core client + EVM well and those that want to cause a chain split

author: holiman
content: One would hope so. OTOH, if one is a bit paranoid, there could very well be competitive projects who'd like nothing more than grief ethereum. And a miner could very well want to 'derail' other miners. If one were paranoid, which I'm not
